timeline.message:
Terrain ListBox to use displayable names

This replaces the old terrain:lvl:exits format with a displayable name.
Quality of Life Changes to the Map Editor
Undo/Redo functions for the Map Editor

Restricted to MUD:1 and MUD:2 as legal mud hexes and changed boards
accordingly, replacing mud:0 and mud:3 and mud:0:1

Restricted to pavement:1 as legal pavement, changed all boards
accordingly

Restricted to SNOW:1 and SNOW:2 as legal snow terrain (thin snow and
deep snow) and changed boards accordingly
Restricted terrain to TUNDRA:1. No board changes necessary.

Bug Fix: Board Tooltips for Bldgs, Bridges and Fuel Tanks now work in
the BoardEditor
Building button change to ease single hex buildings, tooltips
Additional buttons for exits (to be contd) and JLabel click to hide
UI adaptation for the Exits system
No Exits for sub-terrain like BRIDGE_CF
GUI adjustments (Textfield handling), icons, PAVEMENT:1+ legal!
Method name correction and UI fix
Updating Board Editor PR with latest MegaMek, fixing Merge Conflicts
Updated .gitignore to ignore .idea folder, to help with use of Idea IDE
Fixing Help File Location, Image Not Found Bug
Adding Scrollbar to the left-hand side of the editor

timeline.author: sixlettervariables

timeline.bodyText: Why is this using reference equality? This would only work between -128 and 127.
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText:
Why would it only work between those values? Integer is just an int wrapper class, so this is an int to int comparison which should work between -2^-31 and 2^31 - 1.
I've also not found any uses of this in the code, but I believe the reasoning behind it is that this is supposed to be used in terrainType comparisons
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText:
That isn't a comparison of int, that's a comparison of Integer by reference rather than value. Integer values between -128 and 127 tend to be the same reference, but other values will have unique references.
You need to use Integer.equals(val1, val2) or val1.equals(val2) to compare values.
replies.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText:
@sixlettervariables
Unless my testing is incorrect, the caching is only included for Integer to Integer comparisons. This is an int to Integer comparison that will automatically unbox properly. I can share my test code if you'd like to check my math (found it an interesting conundrum and ended up going down the rabbit hole).
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: This was highlighted as an issue when I used SpotBugs, so I'd rather make it explicit we want value comparisons.
replies.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Funny thing is that I made this change for the exact same reason, the Idea IDE pointed this out as a potential bug and this was the suggested fix 😂
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: I guess the different tools have different ways of avoiding the issue. If that was IntelliJ's suggested fix that's fine by me.
replies.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText:
For reference: Integer caches wrapper instances for all values between -128 and 127 and uses a single instance for each of those values no matter where they come from. It also caches any instance created using the valueOf static method for reuse, but not those created with the Integer(int) constructor, which is why that has been deprecated in Java 9. The same is true of the other wrapper classes.
So for comparisons of two Integer objects, == will have the desired outcome if you can guarantee they both within the automatic caching range or were created using valueOf, but equals is preferred as it will work regardless.
In the case of comparison between int and Integer, as in this case, I suspect that other.equals(getTerrainType()), would be less efficient, since it would result in automatic boxing rather than unboxing. Though the compiler may be clever enough to recognize that and use unboxing instead.
replies.author: neoancient
